awd_titl_txt: Regulation of dksA In E. Coli
awd_abstract_narration:
Bacteria rely on numerous global gene regulators to provide rapid benefit or protection from sudden environmental change. DksA, an atypical bacterial gene regulator, plays an essential role in the regulation of transcription (RNA synthesis) of ribosomal RNA (necessary for the synthesis of proteins in the cell) and of other genes involved in important cellular processes. DksA differs from most bacterial gene regulators in that it binds directly to RNA polymerase (the enzyme responsible for carrying out transcription) rather than to DNA.  Little is known about the regulation of DksA itself. Therefore, this project focuses on attaining a detailed understanding of how Escherichia coli cells control the production of DksA in response to different growth conditions.  Preliminary work indicated that the dksA gene is regulated at the level of transcription. The regulation involves two transcription initiation sites, and several other transcription factors.  The dksA gene expression was also found to be controlled at the level of translation (protein synthesis), and this control required a specific portion of the dksA mRNA referred to as the 5'-untranslated region (5'-UTR). One aim of this project is to investigate how dksA is transcriptionally controlled under various different growth conditions. The dksA promoters, which control the initiation of transcription, including a newly discovered promoter, which is most active under conditions of starvation, will be more precisely defined.  The dksA regulatory effects by several suspected transcription factors will be investigated in detail.  The relative transcription activity from all dksA promoters will be simultaneously measured while in their native chromosomal contexts during different growth conditions and in different bacterial strains lacking any of suspected transcriptional regulators.  Another aim is to investigate how dksA gene expression is controlled after the dksA transcript (mRNA) has been made. The project will examine the hypothesis that changes in the rate of breakdown of dksA mRNA during different phases of cell growth contribute to the regulation of dksA expression. The relative DksA protein levels in various E. coli strains and several other bacterial species will be measured during different growth conditions.  The effects of suspected dksA transcription regulators on the cellular levels of DksA protein will also be examined. The RNA structure in the 5'-UTR of the dksA mRNA will be studied.  The project also aims to detect, capture, and identify potential cellular factors that may associate with the 5'-UTR to affect translation control of DksA. Together, these experiments will provide a broad and extensive understanding of the cellular processes used to regulate this important global gene regulator in response to different bacterial growth conditions.

Broader Significance: Knowledge gained from this work will be applicable to other bacteria that are of environmental, industrial, or agricultural importance. Broader contributions will include research training of four graduate and eight to twelve undergraduate students, as part of their education experience at SUNY, Albany.  Research training provided by the PI has thus far resulted in five doctoral graduates, three masters graduates, and twenty three research-trained undergraduate students of diverse race, ethnicity, and gender, that have subsequently succeeded in securing research, academic, or professional careers, or have continued on to acquire graduate or professional education. Synergy between research and teaching will also occur in the role of the PI as instructor of an undergraduate biochemistry laboratory course. The PI will train students in the application of molecular and biochemical approaches, some of which will be used to address aspects of this project.  As a member of an underrepresented group, the PI is in a distinctive position to serve as a role model and mentor for underrepresented students wishing to pursue a career in the sciences. In his roles as coordinator of the undergraduate research program, coordinator of the biochemistry and molecular biology major, and instructor for a biochemistry lab course, the PI interacts with a number of minority undergraduate students with strong academic skills and motivation for research, among which several students will be enlisted to participate in this project and receive research training. The PI will interact with university campuses in Puerto Rico to recruit students to our graduate program and to this research project.  Thus, underrepresented graduate and undergraduate students will be trained to conduct research in this project. Research training supports our nation's research infrastructure and increases appreciation and awareness of the importance of basic science research.

por.por_cntn:
Bacteria display a wide array of strategies to help them survive under different conditions of stress.  In E. coli and other bacteria, the DksA protein plays an essential role in enabling a successful response to various conditions of stress. It is known that DksA acts synergistically with the alarmone (p)ppGpp in binding RNA polymerase to cause repression of a number of genes (including ribosomal RNA genes) required for fast growth and stimulation of a set of genes required in the survival to stress.  It is also known that DksA acts independently of (p)ppGpp (such as when growth conditions are favorable) to regulate the transcription of another set of genes. This work tested the hypothesis that a gene regulator as important as DksA will be subject to mechanisms of regulation beyond what is offered by the changing levels of (p)ppGpp during different conditions of growth.  It was discovered that, in addition to a previously identified promoter for dksA (here referred to as P1), two additional distal promoters (P2 and P3) contribute to the transcription of dskA.  The P1 promoter produces very high levels of mRNA transcripts in cells growing in nutritionally-rich media during the early and mid-exponential growth phase, but the levels decrease over 30-fold during the late exponential and stationary growth phases.  On the other hand, dksA transcripts originating from the P2 and P3 promoters accumulate during the late exponential and stationary phases, but peak at considerably lower levels, compared to the P1 transcripts during mid-exponential growth phase. Western blots designed to compare DksA levels in equivalent quantities of cells showed that DksA accumulates about 8 to 10-fold during the exponential growth phase and decreases again during the stationary phase, consistent with the overall expression pattern of the different dksA transcripts.  The temporal control of the three dksA promoters requires, amond other factors, the stress-related RNA polymerase sigma factor RpoS. As its levels accumulate during entry into the stationary phase, RpoS causes an increase in transcription from the P2 and P3 promoters and a decrease in transcription from P1.  In absence of RpoS , P2 and P3 transcript levels remain low remain low while P1 transcript levels remain high in all stages of growth. This results in about a 4-fold increase in the DksA protein levels during stationary phase, compared to wild type cells, demonstrating that changes in cellular dksA transcript levels result in noticeable changes in  cellular DksA protein levels. Such changes can affect the ability to regulate at least a subset of the DksA regulon.  

DksA and (p)ppGpp were found to exert dual roles on the transcription of dksA.  Like RpoS, they exert negative control over the P1 promoter but positive control over the P2 and P3 promoters in vivo.  Other global gene regulators, such as factor for inversion stimulation (FIS), integration host factor (IHF), and leucine-responsive regulator protein (Lrp), bind the  P1 promoter region to down-regulate its transcription. On the other hand, the cyclic-AMP receptor protein (CRP) binds the P1 promoter region to up-regulate its transcription. DksA expression is also controlled at the level of translation. Genetic and biochemical evidence support the conclusion that two alternative RNA structures can form in the 5?-untranslated region of the dksA RNA to control translation.  At the post-translational level, we find that DksA is phosphorylated at two sites, one of which affects the ability to regulate transcription in vivo.  The results of this work demonstrate that DksA expression is intricately controlled by a number of cellular factors and processes, which can potentially sensitize its cellular expression to various different growth or environmental conditions.  

Broader impacts:

This project supported the training of three full-time graduate students, who were responsible for the bulk of the work, and provided opportunities to train five other rotating graduate students and ten undergraduate students.  It helped broaden the participation of underrepresented groups.  Among the participants in the project, there were seven female, four Asian, five Black, and one Hispanic participant. Among the entire group of participants, nine continued a path toward a research or research-related career. The involvement of many students in this project necessitated an integration of teaching with research. Integration of teaching with research was also staged in an undergraduate laboratory course taught by the PI. Moreover, the PI coordinates and oversees the undergraduate research training of over fifty undergraduate students in the biology department with over fifty investigators across various departments a local research institutions.
